Boulevardier.History: The Boulevardier’s origins can be traced back to the 1920s, and it is believed to have been created as a variation of the Negroni, replacing gin with rye whiskey. It was invented by American journalist, Erskine Gwynne in Paris.

Rum Old Fashioned.History: The Rum Old Fashioned, a classic and flavorful blend of dark rum, Angostura bitters, sugar, and citrus, has captivated taste buds with its rich, complex flavors and timeless appeal. Its origins can be traced back to the late 19th century, and it is believed to have evolved from the Old Fashioned, a cocktail originally made with whiskey.

Ingredients: 1 bottle of dry rose or red wine
50ml fresh orange juice (the fresher the better)
top to 1cm under the rim with fresh coffee

Penicillin.History: While not as life-changing as the antibiotic, the cocktail is just as famous. The Penicilin’s origins can be traced back to 2005, and it is believed to have been created by an Australian bartender Sam Ross at Milk & Honey in New York City.

Ramos Gin Fizz.History: The Gin Fizz is believed to have evolved from the Gin Sling, a cocktail that included gin, lemon juice, and sugar. It was invented in 1888 by Henry C. Ramos at his bar known as the Imperial Cabinet Saloon on Gravier Street, New Orleans, Louisiana.

Pina Colada.History: Three different bartenders claim they created Puerto Rico’s star cocktail, which features coconut cream, rum, and pineapple juice. Ramón “Monchito” Marrero spent months crafting the recipe behind the bar at the Caribe Hilton Hotel in 1954. However, his fellow bartender Ricardo García claims to have made it when a coconut shortage required him to devise a new recipe. A third mixologist, Ramón Portas Mignot, at Barrachina in Old San Juan, also stakes a claim.

Breakfast Martini.History: Despite its name, the Breakfast Martini isn’t a brunch cocktail but rather an imaginative drink conceived originally as a pick-me-up. Created in London sometime during the 90s by bartender Salvatore Calabrese, this citrusy drink was initially mixed for a woman who enjoyed fruity cocktails rather than very dry drinks favored in that era.

Clover Club.History: A pretty pink classic swirling with sweet citrus froth, the Clover Club cocktail has fascinating origins tied to a 19th-century Philadelphia men’s club of literary types who tossed back drinks with names inspired by their academic leanings. This club counted famed poet Edna St Vincent Millay among its members. Both elite and jovial, their bar logo was a four-leaf clover, an emblem that came to attach itself to their eponymous rich, layered gin concoction laced with raspberry overtones. Soft, sweet, and delicately fruity, the Clover Club endures as a symbol of America’s bygone club era and early literary salons.

Zombie.History: Don’t let the name fool you – this beast of a drink is delicious despite its ominous moniker. Invented in 1934 by cocktail pioneer “Don The Beachcomber” at his Hollywood bar, it packs the quintessential rum-citrus tropical punch. The Zombie’s origins are appropriately mysterious. As per Don’s flair for showmanship, he kept the recipe guarded to amp up its mystique but it clearly contains multiple rums and tropical flavors. Potent and strong enough to make patrons feel like “zombies” after a few, it became iconic, inspiring the blender loaded with rum that became synonymous with Tiki bars.

Americano.History: The Americano is a bittersweet and refreshing blend of Campari, sweet vermouth, and soda water. Its origins can be traced back to the 1860s in Milan, Italy, and it is believed to have been created at Gaspare Campari’s Caffè Campari.

Aviation.History: The Aviation soars as an imaginative mixology pioneer. Created in the early 20th century by New York bartender Hugo Ensslin, this gorgeous purple gin sour adds floral crème de violette for a special touch. Ensslin used the newly available crème liqueurs to craft creative, delicate drinks before Prohibition ended cocktail creativity. Named after the exciting new planes gracing the skies in the pioneering airplane age, the Aviation blended science and glamour. After fading away, it was revived in the early 2000s when vintage cocktails came back in vogue. Tart, sweet, and subtly perfumed, this celestial gin sour remains an iconic symbol of the artful, elegant early days of mixology.

Rum Swizzle.History: The Rum Swizzle’s origins can be traced back to the 1930s in Bermuda, where it was created at the swanky bar of the Bermuda Yacht Club. The Rum Swizzle quickly gained popularity among both locals and tourists, becoming a symbol of Bermudian hospitality and a delightful choice for relaxing by the beach or pool.

Planter's Punch.History: The Planters Punch’s origins can be traced back to the 19th century, and it is believed to have originated in Jamaica as a refreshing beverage for plantation workers. The Planters Punch quickly gained popularity among travelers and locals alike, becoming a symbol of Jamaican hospitality and a delightful choice for warm-weather gatherings.

Bramble.History: The Bramble’s origins can be traced back to the 1980s in London, England, and it is believed to have been created by Dick Bradsell at the legendary cocktail bar Dick’s Bar.

French 75.History: The French 75’s origins can be traced back to the 1920s in Paris, France, and it is believed to have been created by Harry MacElhone at the Harry’s New York Bar. The French 75 quickly gained popularity among American expatriates and returning soldiers, becoming a symbol of Parisian glamour and a refreshing choice for special occasions.

White Russian.History: The white russian could be classified as dessert thanks to its easy-drinking combination of vodka, Kahlúa, and cream. The white version sprang up in the 1960s when the black russian got a splash of cream. The only thing either drink has to do with Russia is using the country’s signature spirit.

Elderflower Collins.History: The Elderflower Collins’s origins can be traced back to the 19th century, and it is believed to have evolved from the Tom Collins, a classic cocktail that included gin, lemon juice, sugar, and soda water.

Gimlet.History: The Gimlet is a simple yet sophisticated blend of gin and lime cordial that has captivated the taste buds of millions with its refreshing acidity and straightforward preparation. Its origins can be traced back to the early 1920s, and it is believed to have been created by British naval officers seeking a palatable way to consume lime juice as an anti-scurvy medication. The Gimlet is named after a Royal Navy surgeon – Rear-Admiral Sir Thomas Gimlette.

Pisco Sour.History: The Pisco Sour’s origins can be traced back to the 1920s in Lima, Peru. It was created by bartender Victor Vaughen Morris who owned and operated the Morris’ Bar. According to the Chilean web newspaper El Mercurio Online, Morris invented the drink for his friends as a surprise. It quickly gained popularity among locals and became a symbol of the country’s rich culinary heritage.

Long Island Iced Tea.History: The Long Island Iced Tea is a deceptively refreshing blend of five different spirits. Its origins can be traced back to the 1970s, and it is believed to have been created at the Long Island bar Harry’s 125. Despite its name, the Long Island Iced Tea contains no actual tea, but rather the combination of clear spirits and cola creates the illusion of a refreshing iced tea.

Sazerac.History: The Sazerac takes its name from Sazerac-de-Forge et fils, a French brandy that figured in the cocktail’s original version. Antoine Peychaud mixed the first drink in 1838 in his New Orleans apothecary to serve to his fellow Masons. As the drink evolved, American rye-whiskey subbed in for cognac. It later came to include absinthe and Peychaud bitters. The drink is still synonymous with the Crescent City.

Pimm's Cup.History: British bar owner James Pimm created his eponymous drink between 1823 and 1840. His creation used gin, quinine, and herbs, and quickly became the bar’s specialty — or house cup. When subsequent cups were born with alternate spirits, the original got a number, too — No. 1. Today’s recipe uses gin and sparkling lemonade or ginger ale that’s served with fruit and garnished with mint.

Cosmopolitan.History: Although “Sex and the City” fans may beg to differ, the cosmopolitan’s history predates its days as Carrie Bradshaw’s favorite drink. According to San Francisco bartender John Caine, the drink precedes World War II when it was known as a vodka gimlet. After World War II, it evolved to include French Cointreau along with the vodka and lime, and a new name — “kamikaze.” In the 1980’s, bartenders added cranberry juice to give the drink its iconic blush.

Bellini.History: The Bellini, a refreshing and elegant blend of prosecco and white peach purée, has captivated taste buds with its delicate sweetness and vibrant appearance.Its origins can be traced back to somewhere between 1934 and 1948 in Venice, Italy with its creation credited to Giuseppe Cipriani at Harry’s Bar.

Vesper Martini.History: The Vesper Martini’s origins can be traced back to 1953 when famous author Ian Fleming introduced it in his novel “Casino Royale” as the signature drink of his iconic character, James Bond. In the novel, Bond describes the Vesper as “three measures of Gordon’s, one of vodka, shaken over ice, with a twist of lemon. Preferably in a deep champagne goblet.”

Hemingway Daiquiri.History: The Hemingway Daiquiri, a refreshing and uncomplicated blend of white rum, lime juice, and grapefruit juice, is a beloved cocktail with a rich history and a literary connection. Its origins can be traced back to the 1930s in Havana, Cuba, where it was created at El Floridita bar, a regular hangout for the renowned author Ernest Hemingway. The cocktail quickly gained popularity among Hemingway’s friends and fellow patrons, becoming a symbol of his adventurous spirit and his love for Cuba.

Mai Tai.History: Although others have claimed credit, popular opinion holds that this sugary drink traces its roots to an Oakland, California, restaurant, where Victor Jules Bergeron, aka “Trader Vic,” mixed the first drink in 1934. When he tested a new cocktail with rum, lime, orgeat (almond syrup), orange curaçao, and simple syrup, on his Tahitian guests, they proclaimed “Maita’i roa a’e!” (“Out of this world! The best!”). It was then dubbed the “Mai Tai,” or simply “The Best.”

Paloma.History: The Paloma, a refreshing and tangy blend of tequila blanco, grapefruit soda, and lime juice, is a popular Mexican cocktail with a vibrant and inviting appearance. The Paloma is a mysterious cocktail with its origins remaining a mystery to date. However, there is a recurring theory that the cocktail is named after La Paloma (“The Dove”), the popular folk song composed in the early 1860s.

Bloody Mary.History: This drink may have been named after a British queen — at least according to urban legend — but it was invented in Paris. Bartender Fernand Petiot developed the mixture at Harry’s Bar in 1921. Today’s brunch favorite, which has vodka, tomato juice cocktail, Worcestershire, black pepper, and lemon, was adopted across the Atlantic under the name “The Red Snapper.” It adopted its more famous appellation a decade later. Queen Mary Tudor, whose gory reign inspired her nickname “Bloody Mary,” is thought to have inspired the drink’s current name.

Vodka Martini.History: The Vodka Martini, a refined and timeless classic cocktail, has stood the test of time as a beloved libation. Its origins can be traced back to the early 20th century, and it is believed to have evolved from the Gin Martini. In the USA, the first reference to the Vodka Martini was in a cocktail recipe book published in 1952. The book is called Bottoms Up by Ted Saucier.

Caipirinha.History: Once considered Brazil’s national cocktail, the Caipirinha is now an international classic beloved by millions beyond Brazil. Its origins can be traced back to the early 1900s, and it is believed to have originated in the sugarcane plantations of southeastern Brazil. However, some tales claim it was prepared for the first time as a medicine to ease the effects of the Spanish Flu towards the end of World War I.

Manhattan.History: Popular lore traces the Manhattan’s origins to the Manhattan Club in New York, which still lays claim to the drink. However, cocktail historians trace its genesis to Hoffman House, where bartender William F. Mulhall mixed the drink in the 1860s. Today’s version features just three ingredients: whiskey, sweet vermouth, and bitters.

Moscow Mule.History: The Moscow mule and the copper mug. The two are synonymous with each other, and so are their histories. The drink emerged in 1941 from Los Angeles pub Cock ‘n’ Bull, which had an excess of ginger beer on hand.  Owner Jack Morgan and bar tender Eric Felton both laid claim to the recipe, though Morgan’s claim came with this addendum: his girlfriend owned a company that made copper mugs, and she was a savvy saleswoman. The refreshing drink mixes vodka, ginger beer, and lime.

French Martini.History: The French Martini, despite its name, is not a traditional French cocktail. Its origins can be traced back to the 1980s in New York City, where it was created by bartender Stanley Arrington at the renowned Balthazar restaurant. The cocktail quickly gained popularity for its sophisticated blend of flavors and its elegant presentation

Whiskey Sour.History: The Whiskey Sour’s origins can be traced back to the early 1872 as per the Peruvian newspaper, El Comercio de Iquique. The newspaper wrote that the Whiskey Sour was created by Elliott Stubb who used Limón de Pica for the citrus.

Dark 'n' Stormy.History: The Dark & Stormy’s origins can be traced back to the early 1900s after World War I. As the story goes, the cocktail was born in a Ginger Beer factory that was run by the Royal Naval Officer’s Club in Bermuda. It quickly gained popularity among sailors and tourists, becoming a symbol of the island’s laid-back lifestyle and tropical allure.

Martini.History: The martini is a utility hitter when it comes to libations. The basic ingredients of gin and vermouth can be transformed when combined with other elements, such as espresso. The classic version is garnished with an olive or a lemon twist. The drink is said to date to the Gold Rush era. It hails from Martinez, California, where a resourceful bartender supposedly mixed a miner a celebratory drink with what he had behind his bar: gin, vermouth, bitters, maraschino liqueur, and lemon.

Margarita.History: Its origins can be traced back to the 1930s in the border towns between Mexico and the United States. It is said to have been invented in 1938 by Carlos ‘Danny’ Herrera at his restaurant, near Tijuana, called Rancho La Gloria. In its creation, the cocktail was allegedly created for a famed patron. It quickly gained popularity and became a symbol of Mexican hospitality and a carefree spirit.

Mojito.History: When you drink a mojito, you’re drinking like a pirate — at least according to one of several of the drink’s genesis stories. After English swashbuckler Sir Francis Drake’s 1500s invasion of Cuba was unsuccessful, he (supposedly) mixed the first mojito in Havana. The drink was thought to be medicinal. The combination of white rum — or back then, aguardiente — sugar, lime juice, soda water, and yerba buena or spearmint was thought to cure ailments like scurvy. The drink remains one of Cuba’s most famous cocktails.

Daiquiri.History: Although many cocktails have liquid histories, the daiquiri’s background is more concrete. American engineer Jennings Cox signed an 1896 recipe card that proves its origins. Cox created the drink while in Cuba. He used rum, which was and remains plentiful in the island nation; limes; and brown sugar for sweetness. The cocktail shares its name with the nearby village of Daiquirí.

Aperol Spritz.History: This summer-in-a-glass cocktail mixes Aperol (an Italian bitter apéritif made from bitter and sweet oranges and rhubarb), prosecco, and club soda. Aperol was born in 1919 after Luigi and Silvio Barbieri released orange-hued nip. A few decades later, in the 1950s, the drink was matched with the long-held tradition of the spritz as a pre-dinner drink. The cocktail made its way to the U.S. in the early 2000s.

Negroni.History: Count Camillo Negroni was an exacting customer when, in 1919, he ordered the drink that became the cocktail we drink today. He asked the bartender to replace the soda water in an Americano (a libation with Campari, red vermouth, and soda water) with gin. The bartender did so and swapped out the usual lemon garnish with an orange one. The Negroni was born. Today it’s served with Campari (an Italian bitter), gin, and sweet vermouth.

Pornstar Martini.History: A tempting temptress of a drink, the Pornstar Martini was invented by iconic London bartender Douglas Ankrah. Born in the hedonistic days of the early 1990s at Townhouse restaurant, it mixes velvety smooth vanilla vodka with a hit of passion fruit and bright lime.

Espresso Martini.History: The Espresso Martini was created in the 1980s by Dick Bradsell, a bartender at the Freds Club in London. It is said that Bradsell was asked to make a drink for a woman who wanted something to wake her up. Bradsell combined vodka, espresso, coffee liqueur, and simple syrup, and the Espresso Martini was born.

Old Fashioned.History: The 1862 book “Jerry Thomas’ Bartenders Guide: How to Mix Drinks” hinted at the drink that became the Old Fashioned, though it lacked the libation’s use of whisky. In 1880, Louisville, Kentucky, social club The Pendennis Club brought the modern incarnation to life. James E. Pepper invented the drink, likely with Kentucky bourbon to accompany the bitters, sugar, and plain water that make up this classic. He took the recipe with him to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel bar in New York City where it gained traction.

Screwdriver.History: Although popular history tracks this cocktail’s origins to World War II when American Marines mixed vodka with their orange juice, there’s another plausible story to consider. Some say around the same time, Persian Gulf oil workers started mixing the two ingredients together. When they lacked something to stir their drinks with, they reached for what they had on hand: a screwdriver.

Gin & Tonic.History: Cocktails mixed with tonic gained popularity during the British occupation of India when the soldiers used tonic water containing quinine, created by the bark of cinchona, to prevent and cure the effects of malaria. The tonic was supercharged with quinine, and it was much more potent than what’s used today. Initially, the Brits cut the flavor with sweet spirits, such as rum. Gin was incorporated as early as 1868, when a magazine reported spectators at a horse-racing event in India were asking for the refreshing drink.
